unnormalised: I remember when AI was just something you saw in sci-fi movies, like Terminator or Robot. Now, my cousin, Rohan, is actually working on it at IIT Bombay! He says he's using Python 3.9 and TensorFlow 2.0 to build machine learning models. It's all Greek to me, honestly.
normalised: I remember when A-I was just something you saw in sci-fi movies, like Terminator or Robot. Now, my cousin, Rohan, is actually working on it at I-I-T Bombay! He says he's using Python three point nine and TensorFlow two point zero to build machine learning models. It's all Greek to me, honestly.

unnormalised: He explained it a bit simpler though. He said AI is already everywhere - from recommending videos on YouTube to helping doctors diagnose diseases. He even showed me an article about how AI predicted the stock market with 85% accuracy. He's working on a project to automate customer service for a telecom company. Apparently, they get around 10,000 calls a day!
normalised: He explained it a bit simpler though. He said A-I is already everywhere - from recommending videos on YouTube to helping doctors diagnose diseases. He even showed me an article about how A-I predicted the stock market with eighty five percent accuracy. He's working on a project to automate customer service for a telecom company. Apparently, they get around ten thousand calls a day!

unnormalised: It's amazing how much things have changed in just a few years. I can't even imagine what AI will be capable of by 2030. Rohan thinks we'll have self-driving cars and personalized medicine. Hopefully, it doesn't become like the movies and take over the world! I’m just glad someone I know is contributing to this field; makes it less like magic and more like, well, progress.
normalised: It's amazing how much things have changed in just a few years. I can't even imagine what A-I will be capable of by two thousand and thirty. Rohan thinks we'll have self-driving cars and personalized medicine. Hopefully, it doesn't become like the movies and take over the world! I’m just glad someone I know is contributing to this field; makes it less like magic and more like, well, progress.
